abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Tea Rehabilitation
            and Diversification Project for Sri Lanka was successful.
            The project achieved its main objectives, its impact has
            been significant, its sustainability is likely, and both the
            Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, where large-scale
            introduction of new crops on existing estates is envisaged,
            prior assessment of the technical capability of staff to
            carry out such a program should be required. Second, when
            local procurement of large quantities of highly specialized
            factory equipment is envisaged, the capability of local
            producers to deliver quality products in a timely manner
            needs to be ensured. Third, when launching a major factory
            rehabilitation program, besides renovation, emphasis should
            be given to innovation to modernize the industry and enhance
            productivity. Fourth, tenders for complex technical
            installation, including civil works, equipment, and
            auxiliary supplies, should be issued on a package basis.
            Fifth, adequate staff allocation should be made to ensure
            timely auditing. Lastly, care should be taken in selecting
            suitably qualified consultants to develop monitoring and
            evaluation systems.
